folder: Battery Place & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Battery Place, from Greenwich (left) to West (right) Street's[sic], as viewed northward from Battery Park prior to the completion of the sea retaining wall. In the center is Washington Street. To the left of same are the spires of Trinity Church and St. Pauls Chapel, both on Broadway.
This is a reversed print.

About 1854

Gift of Urbrock Collection

folder: Battery Place and Greenwich Street, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: Three views of a civic reception at the Battery. Views 1 and 2 show the crowds at the foot of West Street. No. 3 is photographed on Battery Place at Greenwich Street.
About 1929
Views 1,2 and 3
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events - Civic Reception.

folder: Battery Place & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
A peanut vendor on the north side of Battery Park and showing also cars on Battery Place with a station of the Sixth and Ninth Ave. Elevated line at Greenwich Street. Prominent structure is the Washington Building which is No. 2 Battery Place.
October 7, 1933.
P.L. Sperr.

folder: Greenwich Avenue & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Greenwich Street, west side, north from but not including Battery Place.
June 2, 1933.
P.L. Sperr.

folder: Greenwich Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Greenwich Street, west side, north from but not includimg Battery
Place.
June 2, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Battery Place & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Battery Place, north side, from Greenwich, to and including West Streets. Prominent building shown, is the Whitehall Building. Piers observed are Pier A, Nos. 1 and 2 Hudson River. The ship is the "Normandie" of
the Compagnie Generale Trans-Atlantique.
July 1935.
P.L. Sperr.

folder: Greenwich Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Greenwich Street, north from Battery Place, showing W.P.A. employees removing the car tracks under the Sixth and Ninth Aves. elevated structure.
July 14, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

folder: Greenwich Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Greenwich Street, north from Battery Place as viewed from the "El" station at that point showing the Ninth Avenue "El" tracks obscuring the street level. At the right are the Washington Building, the Bowling Green Building, the Cunard Building, and the Electric Bond and Share Building. The prominent structure shown to the left and diagonally opposite the last named building is a 35 storied structure bearing No. 21 Rector Street and is recent1y erected.
May 23, 1938.
P.L. Sperr

#12 Greenwich Street and northwards from Battery Place, after removal of "El".
May 4, 1941.
P.L. Sperr

folder: Greenwich Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Greenwich Street, north from Battery Place, as photographed from the downtown "El" platform. Shown are details of the 6th and 9th Avenue "El" station prior to demolition. This is the first station out of South Ferry and is the oldest of any in the city. Charles C. Harvey, the inventor, was permitted to erect an experimental line from this point to 29th Street. Commencing service in 1867 by wire rope locomotion, it failed in 1870 and was succeeded by the N. Y. Elevated Railroad Company. This in turn became the Manhattan Railway Company.
June 7, 1940
Views 1,2
P.L. Sperr

folder: Greenwich Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY
text:
Greenwich Street, north from Battery Place, as photographed from the downtown "El" platform. Shown are details of the 6th and 9th Avenue "El" station prior to demolition. This is the first station out of South Ferry and is the oldest of any in the city. Charles C. Harvey, the inventor, was permitted to erect an experimental line from this point to 29th Street. Commencing service in 1867 by wire rope locomotion, it failed in 1870 and was succeeded by the N. Y. Elevated Railroad Company. This in turn became the Manhattan Railway Company.
June 7, 1940
Views 1,2
P.L. Sperr

folder: Greenwich Street and Battery Place, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
Transportation--Buses: The green buses of the New York Omnibus Corporation at Greenwich Street and Battery Place and at the South Ferry 'El' terminal, Manhattan. Note the pillars of the Ninth Avenue
elevated.
View 1: December 24, 1940
View 2: April 28, 1941

P. L. Sperr
title: Transportation - Buses.

folder: Battery Place & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
2 Battery Place, north side, from Greenwich Street (left) to Broadway (right), showing the 12-story Washington Building that is better known as No. 1 Broadway. On the right appears a view northward on Broadway, across Bowling Green.
1921.
Gift of E.M. Jenks.
